abstracts.cdata!:
The Tenth Railway Project in Pakistan
            was accomplished. Although the Bank financed only 10 percent
            of the railways fifth five-year plan, it contributed to
            reducing the scope of the investments to a more realistic
            level in regard to the limited resources of the country,
            immediate needs of the railways; and the prevention of
            further deterioration of the railways carrying capacity. The
            project objectives were appropriate and the technical
            approaches generally satisfactory. The lessons learned from
            the project have been taken Into account during preparation
            of the Eleventh Railway Project, and are the following, (a)
            since PR's ability to cope with traffic demand depends
            on various factors (such as institutional improvements) the
            Bank has adopted a more conservative approach in freight
            traffic forecasting and any cost reductions expected from an
            improvement in management has not been taken into account in
            financial forecasts, (b) since motive power maintenance was
            the main stumbling block in achieving most of the operating
            efficiencies, this matter has been given top priority in the
            project, (c) the Bank financed study on the future role of
            the railway has given the Government of Pakistan and PR a
            clearer view of the railways deficiencies, its capabilities,
            its economic importance within the transport sector and the
            objectives to be sec in transport planning to allow the
            railway to maintain and improve its role.
